job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Brattleboro, VT
pros: The front line staff are some of the best you'll ever work with. It feels rewarding to be able to help people on their worst days. The pay is pretty competitive and there are always open shifts available at incentivized rates (1.5x or 2x pay) just in case. 12 hour shifts/36 hour weeks mean that you usually get 4 days off a week.
cons: It can sometimes be draining to work with patients for 95-100% of your day.

pros: I held this last position a year and a half and loved it. Great hours and great team. really enjoyed the guests we worked with ( I was a Mental Health Worker at the Retreat for 19 years prior to taking Inn Coordinator position)
cons: To the job itself , there were no cons. But the Retreat "downsized" and eliminated 85 positions and this job was included in the elimination.. To their credit, they did offer a very good severance package. Not a month after our positions were eliminated they announced many more would be eliminated. Hence, why I only give the employer 3 stars.

pros: I found working at the Brattleboro Retreat very rewarding. It has an important mission and you can really make an impact on people's lives. I really liked my coworkers and I always felt that management was trying to improve the organization.
cons: It can be hard and stressful work. The organization has chronic funding challenges with poor insurance and government reimbursements. The union leadership is very negative and can be counterproductive.

job_title: Mental Health Worker in Brattleboro, VT
pros: Good shift differentials/bonuses, opportunities for overtime, fun coworkers
cons: Dysfunctional administration, safety concerns not always listened to, position marketed differently than what the actual job is, minimal upward mobility

review_title: Very "ware-house" oriented - not enough therapeutic treatment - overworked and stressed out employees
pros: Good pay, 5 weeks of paid leave (includes holidays and sick time). Some really wonderful, dedicated people work here. Some of the units are better to work on than others. The climate between the units vary drastically.
cons: Unfortunately, the dedicated people who work here do not stay long due to a "top-heavy" approach in the hospital, where management does not consider the staffs needs very much. Staff gets worked to the bone and when they are burned out they can leave. The leadership makes decisions based on what makes the most sense to them and how quickly and easily one can be replaced, hence people get thrown under the bus without blinking an eye, if it serves the managerial agenda. The place is unionized, which is a true blessing.

pros: The ancillary staff ( the Mental Health Workers) are amazing! They seriously do the frontline hard core hands on work with the patients! It can only be a “labor of love “ because they don’t get paid nearly enough for what they are held responsible for! And they don’t get a lick of credit!
cons: Terrible feeling and energy when you walk into the “hospital.” It is dirty and many times difficult to find a full soap dispenser! There is a “cleaning staff “ but honestly one would never know that to be true!  I would never drop off anyone I love there! Rude people....especially staff!

pros: Beautiful historic campus, dedicated and skilled frontline staff
cons: This organization does not care about their employees. They are understaffed and do little to attract quality applicants. Management and administration are so grossly disconnected from the myriad of problems that exist on the inpatient units. The administration use fear tactics to garner support from the community all the while bashing the floor staff (and each other!) It is grossly mismanaged and disorganized. The Retreat has gained national recognition for its extraordinary care in the past. Since the change in administration within the last two years, it has become one of the most hostile and distrustful organizations I’ve ever worked for. It’s saddening to watch the de-evolution of what was once a lovely place to be part of.

review_title: Difficult job but often personally and professionally rewarding when one is able to surmount challenges
pros: Mission is important, stretches one's professional skills due to diversity of patients, most other employees are dedicated professionals and supportive colleagues, CME opportunities onsite
cons: Leadership not always responsive to concerns of frontline staff, compensation needs adjustment, benefits sacrificed when financial hardship of institution arises, work area in my department was substandard and shamefully shabby

review_title: Challenged organization, maybe about to evolve?
job_title: Inpatient Care Worker in Brattleboro, VT
pros: For part-time flexible work there are opportunities to earn a little better than average for the level of schooling required
cons: Many challenges to grow as a whole organization.  Us-and-Them mentality pervades (administrative vs patient-facing, staff vs patient) must change.  Chronic scrutiny by certifying bodies, state and federal, with problems revealed and restrictions imposed, dampened morale deeply.
